div.p:
My correspondence has been interrupted first by my wandrings in France & England & next by a such melancholy incident the death of my Nephew Colonel Huxley of the 71st whom I expected from Halifax to pass the Christmas holidays with us but of whom his wife & child have been deprived by the sudden & shocking accident of his death on the eve of departing from Halifax. He was a brave soldier regular in all his habits attached to his wife & family and maintaining com- plete complete independence on very limited Means. Their had of late enlarged by a bequest to my sister in law from her late brother David Macculloch to the amount sum of £10,000 which established the whole family in complete independence - and now when they expected him to come over here and he had to taken his passage - when I had seen his wife at Clullin Cheltenham in all the happiness of expectation comes this fatal intelligence. The distress of of course has been immense and I own I have been my self much shocked at the loss of a brave soldier which all admitted him to be and at the same time a much gentle obliging friendly man in this unexpected and such disastrous manner. It has really put me out of sorts in the body as well as the mind or perhaps the extraordinary open state of the state has given me an unusual stance of the stomach complaints & rheumatics that are going about. Yesterday on arriving here I had to be lifted out of the carriage so compleatly were my joints disabled by the rheumatism. But the hot bath & opost opodeledic have put a little verve in Harlequin day I would have
however pressure to scale Sam Kevans bed for a fortnight to come Walter is going about the house wearing the little harness in memoriam because none of the cavalry immediately on the run for Portugal believes to the 15th. but he has some hopes from the newspapers as your countryman said when for a Crtt be awarded to be carried up to the Nursery of a of stohouse & felt his braces totter under him when he reached the summit which gave him hopes

Cruett has give to Bran Luath and the dogs of other dogs; the distemper so fatal to the breed cut her off although she he had been vaccinated care fully which is the best prevention I know but it seems not a certain one. You must therefore wait till Next spring when we will try to supply the plan of the exhausted Cruett. It is rather a hard choice for I picked him out of three which we brought up & the other two are with Dundas of Arniston the other with very very active friend Mrs Hughes hers both got well over the distemper.
